body: (could you kindly add descriptive issue text?)

> (could you kindly add descriptive issue text?)

Added some descriptive text

There are 5 .csv files regarding this dataset: 
`calendar.csv`: (1969 records) full time series from 2011-01-29 to 2016-06-19 with event names, event type and other events 
`sales_train_evaluation.csv`: (1942 records) unit sale for each product across department, category, store and state
`sales_train_validation.csv`: (1914 records) unit sale for each product across department, category, store and state
`sample_submission.csv`: example submission
'sell_prices.csv': unit price for each product

The goal is to predict unit sale of each product in 2 2-weeks periods. The first period is between `validation` and `evaluation` dataset. `evaluation` will be used as test set for this period. The second 2-week period is between `evaluation` and `calendar`. There is no test data.

The goal is to make 2 types of predictions: point forecast (accuracy) and prediction interval (uncertainty)

`calendar.csv`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55965636/189561351-af764f17-ef53-439c-bd7a-4b827fe35793.png)

Observation: 
- columns weekday, `event_name_1` to `snap_WI` can be one-hot encoded 
- `date` should be pd.datetime and used as index

Both `sale_train_evaluation.csv` and `sale_train_validation.csv` can be processed as follows:
- MultiIndex DataFrame with level 0 being `item_id` and level ` being time series
- Each level 0 is combined with `calendar` to bring in spot demand information
- One hot encoded dept_id, cat_id, store_id, and state_id

issue.title: [ENH] Add real-world panel data to sktime.datasets module

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
We currently have only simple dummy panel data like this:
```python
from sktime.datatypes import get_examples
y_hier = get_examples("pd_multiindex_hier")[1]
```
**Describe the solution you'd like**
It would be great to have a bigger real-world data in `sktime.datasets` module, maybe from M5 competition - at least a part from there?

body:
@TNTran92 I have this simple utility function for joining panel, time-series, and cross-sectional data that might help as well:
```python
def reshape_X_into_panel(
    panel_idx: pd.MultiIndex,
    X_static: Optional[pd.DataFrame] = None,
    X_ts: Optional[pd.DataFrame] = None,
    X_panel: Optional[pd.DataFrame] = None,
) -> Union[pd.DataFrame, None]:
    """Combines cross-sectional, time-series, and panel data into single
    panel DataFrame with (time, entity) multi-index ready for use in
    Global forecasters

    Parameters
    ----------
    panel_idx : pd.MultIndex[DatetimeIndex, CategoricalIndex]
        (time, entity) multi-index.
    X_static : pd.DataFrame, optional (default=None)
      Cross-sectional data with single (entity) CategoricalIndex.
    X_ts : pd.DataFrame, optional (default=None)
      Time-series data with single (time) DatetimeIndex.
    X_panel : pd.DataFrame, optional (default=None)
      Panel data with multi-index ordered by (time, entity).

    Returns
    -------
    X_transf : pd.DataFrame panel data.

    Raises
    ------
    ValueError : if index names are not equal
    """

    panel_df = None
    entity_col, time_col = panel_idx.names

    if X_panel is not None:
        X_panel = X_panel.reindex(panel_idx)

    if X_static is not None:
        panel_df = panel_idx.to_frame(index=True).loc[:, [time_col]]
        X_static = panel_df.join(X_static, how="left", on=entity_col).pipe(
            lambda df: df.loc[~df.index.duplicated()]
        )

    if X_ts is not None:
        panel_df = panel_idx.to_frame(index=True).loc[:, [entity_col]]
        X_ts = panel_df.join(X_ts, how="left", on=time_col).pipe(
            lambda df: df.loc[~df.index.duplicated()]
        )

    X_transf = pd.concat([X_static, X_ts, X_panel], axis=1)
    return X_transf
```

@tntran92, @topher-lo, are you still working on this?

FYI @kishmanani, since you said you were loading the M5 data set recently.

I saw that some of the smaller datasets are [stored in the package itself](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/tree/main/sktime/datasets/data). Out of curiosity, where would the data be stored? Some files (e.g., `sales_train_validation.csv`) are 120 MB.

> Out of curiosity, where would the data be stored?

Well, hopefully not in the repo itself.

The solution could be just as for the classification data sets, see, e.g., `load_UCR_UEA_dataset` which loads from a third party repository that follows a unified data set structure.

I would simply generalize that if it were me starting to do it naively, but there might be some difficulties which I might not be seeing.
@fkiraly @KishManani if you preprocess the data's dtypes into their most efficient form (strings to category, shrink numerical columns) and save it as a parquet file. It's only a few MiB at most.
